thread.title: Greece: Decisive EU Leaders' Meeting Cancelled
thread.title_full: Greece: Decisive EU Leaders' Meeting Cancelled

title: Greece: Decisive EU Leaders' Meeting Cancelled
text:
View Photo 

A planned meeting of 28 European Union leaders has been cancelled as crisis talks continue about Greece's place in the eurozone. 
Talks will now be confined to politicians from the 19 eurozone countries suggesting an agreed deal is now closer than suspected. 
Announcing the news, European Council President Donald Tusk said in a tweet: "I have cancelled EUCO (the European Union summit) today," adding that the eurozone summit would be held at 1400 GMT. 
Sky (Other OTC: BSYBF - news ) 's European Correspondent Robert Nisbet said: "The full council of 28 EU leaders was to be convened to discuss emergency measures should Greece find itself falling out of the eurozone, specifically humanitarian aid and how to get banknotes to Greece to put liquidity back into the system. 
"The fact it is now just eurozone leaders meetings suggest they believe there is a kernel of a deal here. 
"This is not specifically the third bailout to be discussed this weekend, it is just the basis of negotiations to organise that third bailout." 
It comes after eurozone finance ministers prepare to reconvene talks on Greece's latest reform proposals, aimed at securing a third bailout of billions in financial support to prevent the country crashing out of the eurozone. 
The talks suspended last night after eight hours were described as "inconclusive" and "very difficult" by the head of the group of finance ministers of countries in the eurozone, Jeroen Dijsselbloem who added that ministers were working towards an agreement. 
"We have had an in-depth discussion of the Greek proposals, the issue of credibility and trust was discussed and also of course financial issues involved, but we haven't concluded our discussions," he told reporters last night. 
"It is still very difficult, but work is still in progress," he added. 
The measures proposed by Greece for a third bailout which won the backing of the Greek parliament late on Friday are aimed offering to implement tax rises and spending cuts in return for a £53.5 billion euro (£38.5 billion) bailout prevent bankruptcy.
